page.title: Coordination Constructions - Lists and Appositives
page.introduction:
Besides the basic coordination constructions where there is an overt conjunction between the conjuncts, nominal phrases especially can have other forms of coordination constructions. We will deal with lists and appositives here.
Lists consist of three or more items that are conjoined to form a single nominal phrase. The initial items are normally separated by commas and there is an overt conjunction before the final item in the list, though there are different possibilities, as in 3-4. Some English examples of nominal phrases consisting of lists are:

EnglishExample.exItem: John and Bill or Sue and Mary
A cat, two dogs, and a chicken but not a monkey

form.prompt: Key how your language expresses lists within a nominal phrase here:
form.introduction: Appositives normally consist of a name followed by a comma and then a description also followed by a comma, or the order may be reversed. Some English examples include:

EnglishExample.exItem: George Washington, the first President of the United States

form.prompt: Key some nominal phrases containing appositives in your language here:
form.instruction: Note that the comma is important in both of these constructions and may be useful in disambiguating list or appositive constructions from other types. You can choose to make the comma (,) a word-formation character in CarlaStudio. Then make it a suffix or enclitic that can go on any word category and give it the feature comma. The PC-Patr grammar constraints to disambiguate via commas are already provided, but you will need to activate them by removing the comment character in the DP rule option conjListAppos. See a similar instruction for topics.
